Award.AwardTitle: Strongly conjugated bacteriochlorin arrays - new near-IR fluorophores and activatable singlet oxygen photsensitizers
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanism (CSDM-B) Program of the Chemistry Division, Marcin Ptaszek from the University of Maryland, Baltimore County will synthesize and study electronic, optical, and photochemical properties of strongly conjugated bacteriochlorin arrays. Bacteriochlorins, which are tetrapyrrolic macrocycles, exhibit strong absorption and emission in the near-infrared spectral window (700-800 nm) and a high yield of singlet oxygen photosensitization; hence they are attractive for a variety of imaging and therapeutic applications. Assembling of bacteriochlorins into strongly conjugated dyads with linkers, which allow extensive electronic communications between bacteriochlorin subunits, results in pronounced alteration of their electronic, optical, and photochemical properties. The goals of the proposed research are to develop an understanding of structure-photophysics relationships in conjugated bacteriochlorin arrays, and to establish their feasibility for ultimately developing long-wavelength fluorophores and activatable singlet oxygen photosensitizers with potential in vivo imaging and therapeutic utility. The influence of the arrays' structure on the absorption and emission wavelengths, quantum yields of fluorescence and intersystem crossing, and intramolecular charge transfer will be studied in detail. Subsequently, activation of fluorescence and singlet oxygen photosensitization by the conversion of strongly into weakly conjugated bacteriochlorin arrays, induced by well-defined chemical transformation, will be studied. The proposed research will provide much deeper understanding of the basic photochemical properties of bacteriochlorin arrays, and greatly expand their potential as diagnostic and therapeutic agents.

The proposed research will advance our understanding of fundamental physicochemical properties of novel molecular architectures, strongly absorbing light in the near-infrared region. This basic research will ultimately lead to the development of novel, light-activated diagnostic and therapeutic agents, which diagnostic and therapeutic functions will be activated only in the target cells. The broader impact of proposed research also includes engagement of graduate, undergraduate, and high school students in highly interdisciplinary research, spanning molecular design, organic synthesis, spectroscopy, photochemistry, and biochemistry. A workshop presenting a fundamental role of photosynthetic pigments in nature, and their diverse applications, ranging from energy-related science to medicine, will be developed and offered for high school students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Photodynamic therapy (PDT) and fluorescence imaging are two noninvasive medicinal therapeutic and diagnostic modalities which utilize light. Both rely on the availability of molecular agents (photosensitizer for PDT, or fluorophore for fluorescence imaging) which, upon absorbing light, either react with oxygen to produce a highly cytotoxic reactive oxygen species (for PDT), or emit photons (for fluorescence imaging). The application of both modalities in human tissue requires that photosensitizer or fluorophore absorb near infrared light (i.e. in 700 – 800 nm), which has deeper tissue penetration than visible light.

Bacteriochlorins are tetrapyrrolic macrocycles, which strongly absorb light in the near infrared spectral window, and they can be utilized for both functions: as photosensitizers for PDT and fluorophores for fluorescence imaging. One of the challenges in the application of bacteriochlorin is limited availability of methods for formulating bacteriochlorin “latent” fluorophores or singlet oxygen photosensitizers, which photochemical functions can be activated in a controlled manner at the target site. Moreover, bacteriochlorins rarely absorb at wavelength  > 800 nm. Thus far, the common ways to tune electronic and photochemical properties of bacteriochlorin include (1) Installation of substituents at the periphery of the macrocycle and (2) metal complexation by four central nitrogen atoms of bacteriochlorins.

The central hypothesis of this project is that assembly of bacteriochlorin into strongly conjugated arrays, i.e. arrays where two bacteriochlorins are connected by a linker which allows a substantial electronic communication between macrocycles, enables achieving novel electronic, optical, and photochemical properties, not attainable for bacteriochlorin monomers. A broad series of strongly and weakly conjugated bacteriochlorin arrays have been prepared to probe the effect of linker type and attachment position, on the properties of resulting arrays. The electronic, photochemical, and electrochemical properties of the resulting dyads have been determined. Bacteriochlorin strongly conjugated arrays exhibit markedly shifted absorption and emission, so that derivatives with absorption and relatively high fluorescence beyond 800 nm have been identified, albeit these arrays feature relatively low yield of reactive oxygen species photosensitization. On the other hand, directly linked (i.e. without any intervening bridge) bacteriochlorin arrays exhibit a relatively high quantum yields of both fluorescence, and reactive oxygen species photosensitization, hence they may function as agents for simultaneous treatment and imaging. All examined bacteriochlorin arrays exhibit a significant reduction of both fluorescence and reactive oxygen species photosensitization in solvents of high polarity. The extent to which photochemical activity of bacteriochlorin arrays is reduced, depends on the linker between macrocycles, and can be tuned by proper molecular design. The electron- and energy transfer properties in directly linked dyads, composed of two different macrocycles, as well as influence of the transition metals [Pd(II) and Cu(II)] on photosensitization of reactive oxygen species, have been studied. Photoinduced electron transfer between bacteriochlorin macrocycles has been proposed to explain the quenching of photochemical activity of dyads in polar solvents.

Photoinduced isomerization of certain conjugated linkers in bacteriochlorin dyads leads to novel derivatives, where conjugation is achieved both through conjugated linker itself as well as through interaction through space due to close proximity of bacteriochlorins. This type of geometry resembles that observed for photosynthetic reaction centers.     

 Obtained results broadly expand our knowledge on the structure – electronic and photochemical properties relationship in bacteriochlorins. Novel architectures developed can be utilized for the construction of long-wavelength fluorescence probes, or activatable reactive oxygen species photosensitizers and fluorophores, for which activity will be silenced in environments of high polarity (such as blood), and activated in low polarity environment (such as intracellular lipid membranes of tumor cells).  

A cohort of post-doctoral researchers, graduate, undergraduate and high school students received vigorous training in organic synthesis, spectroscopy, and photochemistry. Of particular note, high school students were exposed to real scientific research which reinforced their interest to pursue further college education in STEM.
